timeline.bodyText: How can this be non-null?
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I would avoid printing in the agent as this could alter the behavior of the program. In other places the agent uses System.err.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I would mention here that the file in place is a file and that we want to create a dir there.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: In the new version of the code we need to pass an extra argument here. I am working with @d-kozak to see how to do that best.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: Fixed in my branch.
replies.author: vjovanov

timeline.bodyText: I think it would be necessary to use com.oracle.svm.agent.NativeImageAgent#tryAtomicMove as a guarantee that the file will always be complete.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: Fixed. The dumping process is moved to NativeImageAgent , so the class files are written to the same tmp directory along with other configuration files, no need to maintain an independent dumping process here any more.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I don't see why we would fail here. I think we should simply not collect those classes ATM. Actually, we could even collect them because in the future we definitely want to support the calls with the protection domain.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: Reporting at collecting time would let the user know the program is not supported as early as possible, so they don't have to wait to image compilation time or runtime. This unsupported message is reported at unLoad time so it wouldn't interfere the configuration collecting process.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText:
One of the use cases for the agent is automatic collection of profiles in the cloud setting. For this purpose, I would like to have the agent behave exactly the same as the original.
Could we put this kind of reporting behind a flag?
replies.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: removed the reporting here.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I think this data structure needs to handle concurrent updates?
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Why not use SHA-256 or SHA-512 that are standard and can be used from any other language/tool?
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: I concerned the runtime performance. Here is not for security purpose to protect the class from malicious attach, but only for consistency verification, SHA-256 would be too heavy. But if there is a requirement to extend to other languages or tools, we can choose other standard but faster algorithms such as MD5.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText:
SHA-256 is about 11 cycles per byte. For a 10 kB class this would be 110k cycles or roughly 30 us.
I think that is OK given that the VM will anyhow need to load, verify, interpret, and compile that code.
replies.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I think it would be better to keep the dynamic classes in the same folder as other configs. This way it will be easier to use native image with -H:ConfigurationFileDirectories=. This is, for example, the case in our benchmarks.
timeline.author: vjovanov

replies.bodyText: Agreed, as discussed previously (#2442 (comment) and #2442 (comment)). I'll trace all dynamic generated classes in a new configuration file and store all generated classes under the same directory.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText:
Thank you for your comments @vjovanov 👍
@ziyilin , please do address #2442 (comment) and #2442 (comment) and also consider which suggestions from the object serialization PR might apply here as well. Then I will review in more depth.
replies.author: peter-hofer

timeline.bodyText:
This seems unused now, please remove if that is the case.
Please check the entire PR for unused code and unnecessary whitespace changes.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: This is not an issue that needs to be handled or reported in the agent, but should be reported during the image build or at image runtime.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Removed.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText: unsupportedExceptions and reportExceptions are unused now.
replies.author: peter-hofer

timeline.bodyText: This will execute postDefineClass twice because we are currently inside it in the breakpoint and will continue executing there after returning. It also seems unnecessary because the class is already loaded and postDefineClass does nothing of significance and is private, so it cannot be overridden in subclasses.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed by changing postDefineClass method to onClassFileLoadHook method.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Please undo this and instead wrap the exception in an unchecked (runtime) exception where it is thrown.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Why not use the ClassFileLoadHook event instead? It provides the class name and bytes directly without having to extract them from parameters and locals.
timeline.author: peter-hofer
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -573,6 +593,96 @@ private static boolean handleGetSystemResources(JNIEnvironment jni, Breakpoint b
         return true;
     }
 
+    /**
+     * java.lang.ClassLoader.postDefineClass is always called in java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass,
+     * so intercepting postDefineClass is equivalent to intercepting defineClass but with extra
+     * benefit of being always able to get defined class' name even if defineClass' classname
+     * parameter is null.
+     */
+    @SuppressWarnings("unused")
+    private static boolean postDefineClass(JNIEnvironment jni, Breakpoint bp) {

replies.bodyText: You are right. I have removed the postDefineClass method and added a new method onClassFileLoadHook instead.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Please reuse the existing AccessAdvisor object and for brevity also the LazyValueUtils methods (with static imports).
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed as the whole postDefine method is removed.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I don't think it's necessary to instantiate this class, it should be fine to pass everything as arguments to trace and pass needed values on to other methods at that point.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed by making trace method static.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Please clean up visibilities and modifiers in the entire PR: none of the members in this class need to be protected as far as I can tell and should be either private or package-visible and potentially final.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed by removing them.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: I don't think any of these have to be public.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: This is slow. If checks like this cannot be avoided, compare against a jmethodID from the handle set.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed as the whole postDefine method is removed.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText:
This seems expensive and I am not convinced of the $/$$ heuristic either. But there is no single perfect way to determine whether a class was generated.
However, have you looked into the supplied ProtectionDomain object and its CodeSource object? It seems like an equally good indicator whether that object or its return value for getLocation are null and querying them is cheap.
(The question of where to draw the line here is tricky. For example, we probably want to capture classes from the network or from nested JARs which do have a valid URL. I suppose we will have to improve this for cases like that over time.)
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText:
I have removed the $/$$ way.
This part of code is now working inside the onClassFileLoadHook. There are 3 checks:

if the classloader is null, it is not dynamic class
if the class name is null, it is the dynamic class
Still check via getResource

There is still no guarantee that a dynamic class always has a null ProtectionDomain or null CodeSource.location. User can provide any ProtectionDomain to defineClass.
getResource is slow, but is accurate.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText: Do you have an example for a custom class loader that provides a ProtectionDomain and CodeSource with a URL while getResource for the same class would return null?
replies.author: peter-hofer

timeline.bodyText: Why p.getResourceConfiguration()? Is this even necessary?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: I've changed it to p.getDynamicClassesConfiguration().
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Why not use traceCall? Everything can be put in args.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: This should be inconsistent with the other styles and a bit shorter perhaps, how about --dynamic-classes-input/-output? In fact, I think we should drop the extra loading in other places too.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed, and all loading post-fixes are removed.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Dead code?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Removed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Why are the changes in this class needed when there is ConfigurationDynamicClass?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Removed.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Misses checks for extraneous items.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: What about other characters that are valid in a class name, but not in the file system, or limits for file name or path lengths? This should be more defensive and handle having more than one class with the same name.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText:
As now I directly read the class file into byte array to call defineClass instead of finding class from class path, there is no need to keep the package information in the file name. Actually the file name can be anything that is unique.
What do you think using the already calculated SHA value as file name? In this way the file name is unique, and furthermore, we can save one entry in configuration file. As the file name is from SHA, only one of classFile and checksum entry is needed.
replies.author: ziyilin

replies.bodyText: Yes, I believe the way forward is using a unique hash code in the file name, potentially the unqualified name too for identifiability to the developer.
replies.author: peter-hofer

timeline.bodyText: Dead code?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Removed this case. Not needed any more.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Why not simply static methods?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: What's the reason behind not supporting this? Can't we set the protection domain on the class object (e.g. indirectly through a map), or ignore it? Or is this some esoteric case?
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: defineClass APIs with ProtectionDomain parameter will call ClassLoader.checkCerts method to check if the class' certs match with the other same-package-classes'. However, Substrate VM does not store certs files from jar files to native image at build time, so there is always nothing to compare at image runtime. If the API is supported now, it behaves differently from what JDK does. I think finding a proper solution to reserve jar's certs files is beyond this PR's scope, so I leave these two APIs as unimplemented for now.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: The hash code should be kept in a compact byte array (should be converted during parsing).
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed by changing dynamicGeneratedClasses to EconomicMap<String, byte[]>
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Needs proper rethrowing.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Fixed.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText: Not clean and the static field will not work when there is more than one image build in the process (server mode). You might need to add a method to collect the locations and return them so you can use them in the feature's afterRegistration method.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Removed the dynamicClassLoadingDirs. The original way is to fetch the dumped class file from all possible locations setting by -H:DynamicClassesConfigurationFiles= and -H:DynamicClassesConfigurationResources= , but the class file should be located in the dynClasses directory under the configuration file's directory. So we only need to follow the location of the currently parsed dynamicClass configuration file to look for the dumped class files.
replies.author: ziyilin

timeline.bodyText:
Assuming that the image class loader is a URLClassLoader and manipulating it through reflection does not seem like a good idea at all (especially with the module system). These steps need proper support in ImageClassLoader and AbstractNativeImageClassLoaderSupport and its subclasses and that probably entail creating a ClassLoader subclass for these purposes.
Moreover it seems very roundabout and not safe to reconstruct a class directory hierarchy, add it to the loader's class path (which potentially) and load the class from there. Is it not possible to just load the class from a byte array with the file's contents (other than that we need to call defineClass somehow)?
This really needs fixing.
timeline.author: peter-hofer

replies.bodyText: Now read the class file into byte array and then reflectively call defineClass with the byte array data.
replies.author: ziyilin
